column1: CPIAUCNS~CPIAUCNS~2001-07-23~2001-07-23~Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers: All Items~1913-01-01~2001-06-01~Monthly~M~Index 1982-1984=100~Index 1982-1984=100~Not Seasonally Adjusted~NSA~2008-11-20 09:04:26-06~73~95~Handbook of Methods - (https://www.bls.gov/opub/hom/pdf/cpihom.pdf) Understanding the CPI: Frequently Asked Questions - (https://www.bls.gov/cpi/questions-and-answers.htm)~10

CPIAUCSL~CPIAUCSL~2001-07-23~2001-07-23~Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers: All Items~1947-01-01~2001-06-01~Monthly~M~Index 1982-1984=100~Index 1982-1984=100~Seasonally Adjusted~SA~2008-12-16 14:45:08-06~94~95~"The Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers: All Items (CPIAUCSL) is a price index of a basket of goods and services paid by urban consumers. Percent changes in the price index measure the inflation rate between any two time periods. The most common inflation metric is the percent change from one year ago. It can also represent the buying habits of urban consumers. This particular index includes roughly 88 percent of the total population
column9: and those not in the labor force.

column1: The CPIs are based on prices for food
column4: and fuels; transportation fares; service fees (e.g.
column5: water and sewer service); and sales taxes. Prices are collected monthly from about 4
column7: 000 retail establishments across 87 urban areas. To calculate the index
column8: price changes are averaged with weights representing their importance in the spending of the particular group. The index measures price changes (as a percent change) from a predetermined reference date. In addition to the original unadjusted index distributed
column9: the Bureau of Labor Statistics also releases a seasonally adjusted index. The unadjusted series reflects all factors that may influence a change in prices. However
column10: it can be very useful to look at the seasonally adjusted CPI
column11: which removes the effects of seasonal changes

column1: The CPI can be used to recognize periods of inflation and deflation. Significant increases in the CPI within a short time frame might indicate a period of inflation
column2: and significant decreases in CPI within a short time frame might indicate a period of deflation. However
column3: because the CPI includes volatile food and oil prices
column4: it might not be a reliable measure of inflationary and deflationary periods. For a more accurate detection
column5: the core CPI (CPILFESL (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CPILFESL)) is often used. When using the CPI
column6: please note that it is not applicable to all consumers and should not be used to determine relative living costs. Additionally
column7: the CPI is a statistical measure vulnerable to sampling error since it is based on a sample of prices and not the complete average.

column1: For more information on the consumer price indexes
Bureau of Economic Analysis. ""CPI Detailed Report."" (https://www.bls.gov/cpi/) 2013.
Understanding the CPI: Frequently Asked Questions (https://www.bls.gov/cpi/questions-and-answers.htm)"~10

CPILFENS~CPILFENS~2001-07-23~2001-07-23~Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers: All Items Less Food and Energy~1957-01-01~2001-06-01~Monthly~M~Index 1982-1984=100~Index 1982-1984=100~Not Seasonally Adjusted~NSA~2005-06-08 15:38:06-05~54~83~The “Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers: All Items Less Food & Energy” is an aggregate of prices paid by urban consumers for a typical basket of goods
column2: excluding food and energy. This measurement
column4: ” is widely used by economists because food and energy have very volatile prices. The Bureau of Labor Statistics defines and measures the official CPI
column5: and more information can be found here: https://www.bls.gov/cpi/questions-and-answers.htm or here: https://www.bls.gov/opub/hom/pdf/cpihom.pdf.~10
